Cf. Costco Wholesale Corp., 358 NLRB No. 106, slip op. at 1–2 (Sept. 7, 2012) (finding employer’s policy prohibiting employees from making statements “thatdamage the Company, defame any individual or damage a person’s reputation” to be unlawful because the rule had no “accompanying language that would tend to restrict its application” to legitimate business concerns); Knauz BMW, 358 NLRB No. 164, slip op. at 1 (Sept. 28, 2012) (finding employer’s “courtesy rule,” which prohibited “disrespectful” conduct and “language which injures the image or reputation” of the employer, to be unlawful, because nothing in the rule or elsewhere in the employee handbook “would reasonably suggest . . . that employee communications protected by Section 7. . . are excluded from the rule’s broad reach”).

Topic.Title: What does the Bible say about homosexuality?

Message.Msg: juanruiz, I would have loved to have been able to ask Apostle Paul about some of his opinions. For example, he talked about long hair as a "shame" for a man. (1 Cor 11:13-16). In the 1970's, the Christian churches, responding to the "long hair" revolution, were abuzz on the subject - often quoting these verses. But, they did not really emphasize verse 16, where Paul admits, "If anyone wants to be contentious about this, we have no other practice—nor do the churches of God." Aha! In other words, he was giving his (considered and well respected) opinion - nevertheless, an opinion. He was a spiritual leader for the time, encouraging Christians to set themselves apart for Christ - even to be celibate to lessen the distraction of family from being able to do all that could be done for the cause. I am sure that he was aware that Sampson had long uncut hair - by direction of the Lord. OK, maybe a special case. On Paul's clearly theological discussions, I find no fault, and they are timeless. Some casual ("only on rare holidays") readers of the Bible may not be able to distinguish between opinion and theology. BB

Message.Title: Boeing traces faulty fire extinguishers to supplier WSJ- OUTSOURCING ?
Message.Msg: Boeing traces faulty fire extinguishers to supplier - WSJ • Fri Aug 16, 2013 1:47am EDT Aug 16 (Reuters) - Boeing Co has traced the incorrectly assembled engine fire extinguishers on 787 Dreamliners to the manufacturing of bottles at a supplier's facility(outsourcing) while saying there were no risks to flight safety( sure you bettya), the Wall Street Journal reported. On Wednesday, Japanese airline ANA Holdings said it had found an electrical wiring problem in the fire extinguishers of the engines of three of its Boeing Dreamliner jets. The problem was first discovered during pre-flight maintenance of a jet at Tokyo airport. Boeing said in a written statement to the Wall Street Journal that the improper assembly, which has been confirmed to have been found on three ANA jets in Japan, "does not present a safety of flight issue because the bottles are not the only means of fire extinguishing for engines( oh good, Boeing, then let’s take one of the fire extinguishing features not working as a no problem then, that is called enablement) and there are multiple redundancies within the fire extinguishing system. "THE PILOT CAN PUT THE 787 INTO A DIVE, THAT WILL THRILL THE PASSENGERS ! A Boeing spokeswoman told the newspaper that activating the 787's engine fire extinguishing system "does not disable or impact [the engine's] performance." WOW IT MIGHT BE GOOD FOR THE JET ENGINE NOW RIGHT "Regardless, improperly configured components are not acceptable and this issue is being addressed promptly( just like all the other past 787 issues , the 787 grounding and the several late delivery issues to fix all those cheap outsourcing issues and still the problems exist ). Boeing will follow standard disciplined procedures to understand how this discrepancy occurred and ensure it is not repeated,"

Message.Title: Obama’s Economic Approval Slips to 35%
Message.Msg: Lydia Saad Gallup August 15, 2013 Despite President Barack Obama’s renewed focus on the nation’s economy this summer, he scores worse with Americans on the economy than he did in June. His approval rating on the issue, now 35%, is down seven percentage points, and his ratings on taxes and the federal budget deficit are each down five points. During the same period, his overall approval rating is down three points.

Message.Title: Russia selling airbus stake
Message.Msg: (Reuters) - Russian state development bank Vnesheconombank, or VEB, is continuing to sell down its 5.02 percent stake in Airbus's parent EADS (EAD.PA) with the proceeds destined for local plane maker Sukhoi, Vedomosti newspaper said on Friday. In a July 26 filing in the Netherlands, where EADS is registered, VEB had already reported a reduction in its stake to 2.88 percent, the paper said

Topic.Title: What does the Bible say about homosexuality?

Message.Msg: "He's no different than ..." The kicker here is that the Bible says of itself, "All scripture is given by inspiration of God..." (2 Tim 3:16-17, written by Apostle Paul), which forces one into a more clearly defined position of support or opposition to itself. Even Paul's exhortations (or seeming opinions) are God inspired. Anything that then disagrees with the Bible, such as the Koran, cannot be inspired by God (of the Bible) as God is perfect and cannot be the author of confusion (1 Cor 14:33). It does not allow ambivalence, but requires a decision (Revelation 3:16-20). And, even though we reject Him, He pursues us (Romans 5:8). One must be careful not to think that turning to God is an "end of life" decision as we do not know what the next day will bring (James 4:14). And, instead, Solomon and Isaiah wrote, "Seek the Lord while He may be found" (Ecclesiastes 12:1, Isaiah 55:6-7)

Message.Title: EMARSS milestone
Message.Msg: FAIRFAX, Va., Aug. 15, 2013 – Two Boeing [NYSE: BA] Enhanced Medium Altitude Reconnaissance and Surveillance System (EMARSS) aircraft have arrived at Aberdeen Proving Ground in Maryland for airborne tests of the target-tracking capabilities they will provide to the U.S. Army. The extensively modified Beechcraft King Air 350 ER aircraft will undergo mission systems calibration and testing to certify them prior to delivery. “It’s gratifying to see this innovative program reach the next stage of development, one step closer to delivering to our customer,” said Mark Stephenson, EMARSS program manager for Boeing. “The flights to Aberdeen from Kansas were an achievement themselves, and they paved the way for airborne evaluation and testing against a range of targets.” EMARSS aircraft are designed to detect, locate, identify and track surface targets, day or night, in almost any weather conditions. They will provide soldiers with intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance capabilities as well as communications and targeting. Boeing’s Engineering, Manufacturing and Development contract with the Army calls for four development aircraft as well as logistics services.

Topic.Title: What does the Bible say about homosexuality?

Message.Msg: juanruiz, There is much debate out there on this subject. While the Bible "canons" (Catholic and non-Catholic) were formed and agreed upon about 1600 AD, the content (at least common content) selected is authentic and proven to be original. Literally tens of thousands of whole and fragmented copies, some dating back to within the first 100 years of Jesus' death and resurrection, are available and warehoused in universities around the globe. Google it. Various versions of translations, in addition to separate target languages, range in consistency to the original Greek and Hebrew from outright fraud (adding to and taking away) to reasonable and pure in intent and faithfulness to the original text. You can look at the original Greek and Hebrew at the "biblos" website. At some point, one might ask, "why am I here and what is my purpose?" Given that a God is One Who created the entire universe and is perfect in purpose and holiness, it is reasonable to argue or believe that such a Person would have shepherded His message to man, His creation of love, with equal purpose and perfection - versus not knowing until after death, when it is too late. It is a matter of faith and no amount of straining of the lungs in debate will lead anyone to their own conclusion. BB

Message.Title: Only in Texas.....
Message.Msg: Texas Police Raid Farming Commune After Mistaking Tomato Plants For Marijuana (Disinformation website) By Jacob Sloan on August 15, 2013 Perhaps to be on the safe side, we should prohibit growing plants in general. NBC 5 Dallas–Fort Worth reports: A small organic farm in South Arlington is demanding an apology from police who raided the property in early August. Officers raided the Garden of Eden, a 3.5-acre farm, searching for marijuana in the gardens, according to search warrants. Police did not any drugs. Quinn Eaker, a resident, told NBC 5 that the six adults who live at the farm were handcuffed when SWAT officers from the Arlington Police Department came to their home with weapons drawn. According to a statement posted on the Garden of Eden’s website, the raid of the farm lasted for an estimated 10 hours. Code compliance officers mowed the grass on the property and removed wild, cultivated plants including blackberries and okra. Eaker said that the plants police mistook to be marijuana were likely tomatoes: “They can’t even tell the difference between tomato plants and a marijuana drug cartel.”

The award follows the integration of Meggitt’s established fire detection and control capability with the fire suppression equipment of recently-acquired Pacific Scientific Aerospace business, HTL. Dennis Hutton, President of Meggitt Safety Systems, explained: “The ability for suppliers to offer complete ATA Chapter 26 fire protection systems has become increasingly important as aircraft manufacturers continue to simplify procurement and logistics. Message.Title: Boeing is scaring the 787 Flying public, blames Fire suppresion supplier , not BA - QA! and want Airlines to inspect
Message.Msg: Boeing should have caught this problem with on site BA QA inspection at the supplier, next at boeign receiving, next at assembly with install mechanic and QA, then at the flight line test, and finally at actual flight testing. Instead Boeing wants their plane inspected by customer workers with a cheat sheet on how to do it. This is the best way Boeing can demonstrate their outsourcing business model does not work, any better than the company they got the idea from MD , a bankrupted outsource company, read JOHN HART-SMITH Japan’s All Nippon Airways Co. (ANA) has found another problem on the 787 Dreamliner from Boeing Co. (BA). On Wednesday, a flight from Tokyo to Frankfurt was delayed due to faulty wiring in a fire suppression system for one of the plane’s engines. According to reports, the system may activate a fire extinguisher on the wrong engine in the event of a fire on one of the 787’s two engines. Boeing’s solution is to ask airlines to check their own 787s using an instruction sheet the aircraft maker will supply. Boeing is blaming the problem on the supplier, Kidde, a division of United Technologies Inc. (UTX), which said it is working to resolve the issue. BOEING SELECTED THEIR SUPPLIER AND IS RESPONSIBLE TO ASSURE THE QUALITY OF THE PRODUCT WORKS PER PLAN QA SHOULD BE ABLE TO DETECT ANY VENDOR PROBLEM AT VENDOR SHOP, THEN AT BOEING RECEIVING, THEN ON THE PLANE AT INSTALL OR REVIEW OF THE VENDOR PART AS INSTALLED WHEN IT ARRIVES AT THE BOEING FACTORY, THEN ON FLIGHT LINE ON A STATIC TEST AND FINALLY AFTER A CUSTOMER QA REVIEW AND FINAL TEST FLIGHT BEFORE THE 787 LEAVE THE FACTORY TO THE CUSTOMER BOEING SHOULD CHECK AND VERIFY THEIR OWN PRODUCT IS GOOD NOT WAIT UNTIL ANOTHER TEETHING PROBLEM COMES UP AND BLAME SOMEONE ELSE FOR BOEINGS LACK OF MANAGEMENT ABILITY

Topic.Title: Boeing is scaring the 787 Flying public, blames Fire suppresion supplier , not BA - QA! and want Airlines to inspect

Message.Msg: An FAA audit of Boeing's supplier control procedures was part of the production certificate for the 787. Mistakes can happen, but something like this should have been discovered during a functional test for the plane. August 26, 2011 EVERETT, WA – Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Administrator Randy Babbitt today announced that the FAA has approved production of the Boeing 787 Dreamliner. At an event at Boeing’s facility in Everett, Washington, Administrator Babbitt presented Boeing executives with two certificates for the design and production of the Boeing 787 Dreamliner with Rolls-Royce engines. The first, a Type Certificate, is for the FAA’s approval of the airplane’s design. The second, a Production Certificate, allows Boeing to manufacture the 787 following a rigorous review by FAA inspectors of Boeing’s quality system, production tooling, manufacturing processes and controls, inspection methods, and supplier control procedures.

Message.Title: Kiddie Fire Supression System
Message.Msg: Not sure if Airbus uses any of their hardware, but it appears at a minimum they do use their training. Kidde Fire Trainers, Inc. has delivered the world's first CAT 10 Aircraft FIRETRAINER® (A-380 Type) Simulator. The system was completed for the SERCO International Fire Training Centre in Durham Tees Valley, United Kingdom, in October 2007 and features 17 distinct fires. The "crashed aircraft" configuration simulates a major fuselage split. Aircraft FIRETRAINER® Systems can be fueled by multiple fuels, including LPG, Kerosene, and Carbonaceous.

Topic.Title: Which is better, Joseph Goebbels or Wayne Dickley?

Message.Msg: "Boeing does not need any reason to Terminate VN ..." Wanna bet? My peers and I are represented by a union (SPEEA). All of the terms and conditions of our employment are guaranteed by a legally-binding contract between Boeing and that union and in that contract is language that prevents Boeing from terminating us "at will" (i.e. on a whim, for no other reason than it's what they want to do). We can only be terminated "for cause", which basically means for committing a gross violation of company rules and/or policies or repeated instances of lesser violations. I have committed neither and you are essentially threatening me with an empty bag. Yeah, good luck with that. "... its called employee at will, ..." Wrong. It's called "employment at will" and neither I nor any of my peers are employed in that fashion. If you had ever worked for Boeing you'd know all of this stuff cold, but as usual you don't know jack. Nice try. Wanna try again?

Message.Title: UTX admits to BA 787 error
Message.Msg: A unit of United Technologies Corp. said Friday it is responsible for assembly errors in engine-fire extinguishing systems supplied for Boeing Co. 787 jets. Improperly assembled extinguisher bottles were found on three All Nippon Holdings Inc. 787s in Japan on Wednesday, spurring a round of Boeing-recommended inspections by operators ."An assembly error in our service center impacted a limited number of refurbished fire extinguisher bottles," said a spokesman for United Technologies in an emailed statement. The parts were manufactured at the company's Kidde Aerospace unit. The company said that the "error has been corrected and we are working with Boeing and the airlines to complete the necessary inspections, which we expect will be completed over the next few days."

Message.Title: Liberals Upset Over Welfare Drug Testing
Message.Msg: By Travis Melvin on August 16, 2013 chicago_housing_authority It has been standard policy for years that for anyone living in government-subsidized housing in Chicago must undergo annual drug testing. The rationale is that taxpayers don’t want to hand out their hard-earned money to support a person’s drug habit. In many other areas of welfare, people are also asked to be tested before given handouts. Now, liberals are saying this goes too far. The ACLU has filed a lawsuit in US District Court claiming that the practice is “humiliating and invasive” and that for people asking for the hand out it “stigmatizes (them) as a presumptive criminal and drug user.” They point out that most subsidized housing around the country does not require a drug test and call the practice “very rare”. The Chicago Housing Authority put this in place due to the rampant drug use and narcotic sales going on in its public housing. During the 80s and 90s, they were seen as a national symbol for failed public housing. The public housing buildings, especially in the area known as Cabrini Green, which is the area that is specifically under scrutiny in this law suit, had record high crime numbers and a shocking level of violence. It got so bad that the large buildings were demolished and smaller units were built to make policing the area more manageable. The numbers show this policy has been effective and the crime rate in that area has declined since the drug testing policy went into effect. Liberals, of course, disagree and would prefer taxpayer money to be handed out without any controls. whoring themselves for the vote. These people would kill a baby for the vote, but I think they do via abortions.
